title: Angular Momentum - Comparing L vs t two objects

content.question: Two objects, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, each experience a net external torque that varies over an interval of <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math> seconds. Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> has a rotational inertia that is twice that of Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>. The graph shown represents the angular momentum of the two objects as functions of time between time <math alttext="t equals 0 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> and <math alttext="t equals 5 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>. The average magnitudes of the net torques exerted on objects <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> from <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 5 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> are <math alttext="tau sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="tau sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math>, respectively. Which of the following expressions correctly relates the magnitudes of the average torques?

choices.label: <math alttext="tau sub B, equals 4 tau sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="tau sub B, equals 2 tau sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="tau sub B, equals one half tau sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="tau sub B, equals one fourth tau sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>4</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="tau sub B, equals 2 tau sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>τ</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>

unit.text: 6: Energy and Momentum of Rotating Systems

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
